summary.seg: This small manuscript contains a Greek grammar by Antonius Arcudius (Antonio Arcudi, 1554-1612), archpriest from Soleto in Apulia in Southern Italy. Arcudius is known for having composed the Neon Anthologion, a breviary in Greek to be used for individual prayer by all the people living in Italy observing the Byzantine rite, which was printed in Rome in 1598 ( Νέον Ἀνθολόγιον πληρέστατόν τε καὶ ἀκριβέστατον εἰς τὸ τὰς νυχθημέρου κανονικὰς ὥρας τε καὶ δεήσεις ἀναγνώσκειν, συντεθὲν καὶ συλλεχθὲν, κατὰ τὴν τάξιν τοῦ παλαιοῦ καὶ καθολικοῦ τυπικοῦ τῆς παραδόσεως τῶν ἁγίων πατέρων, τοῦ τε ἁγίου Σάβα, καὶ τοῦ Στουδίτου καὶ τὸ πλεῖστον τοῦ Ἁγίου Ὄρους, οὐ μὴν δὲ ἀλλὰ καὶ μέρος τῆς παραδόσεως τοῦ ὁσιωτάτου πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωσὴφ τῆς μονῆς τοῦ ἁγίου Νικολάου τῶν Κασούλων. Ἐτυπώθη ἐν Ῥώμῃ ͵αφϙη΄. Ἐκ τῆς Βατικανῆς Τυπωγραφίας) (on Arcudius' Neon Anthologion see, among others, C. Korolevskij, 'La codification de l’Office byzantin. Les essais dans le passé', in: Orientalia Christiana Periodica 19 (1953), pp. 25-58). This initiative fell within the framework of a policy of reform adopted by the Roman Church, after the Council of Trent, towards the Greek communities observing the Byzantine rite present in Italy, in particular in the southern regions: these, although officially falling under the jurisdiction of the Roman catholic hierarchies, were often still tied to the Eastern Church. Among the questions touched upon, there are, for example, the selection of the books to be used in the Byzantine liturgy, or the ordination of the Byzantine secular clergy in Italy.

Antonius Arcudius is reported to have been a Greek teacher, and in particular to have been the teacher of Pietro Lasena (1590-1636), antiquarian and historian of the Reign of Naples (he compiled: Dell'antico ginnasio napoletano opera posthuma di Pietro Lasena, published in Rome in 1641 and in Naples in 1688), but until now almost nothing was known about this. The circumstance was known thanks to the accounts in J.-J. Bouchard, Petri Lasenae Vita (Romae, 1637), p. 8, and P. Giannone, Istoria civile del regno di Napoli (Milano, 1821), 8, p. 352. Only recently a grammatical fragment attributed to Antonius Arcudius has been found by Roberta Durante in the archive of S. Caterina in Galatina (see R. Durante, 'Nuove testimonianze dal Salento ellenofono: personaggi, testi e disegni in copertina tra tardo Medioevo ed età moderna', in: Manoscritti italogreci: nuove tessere in un mosaico frammentario, a cura di S. Lucà, con la collaborazione di D. Bucca e F. D'Aiuto (Roma, 2020), pp. 253-270). This manuscript, which contains a grammatical work by Arcudius, copied by his student Pietro Lasena, could shed more light on this little known aspect of the life of the archpriest of Soleto.

msItem.author: Antonio Arcudi
msItem.title: De Constructione Verborum
msItem.rubric: f. i recto Περὶ συντάξεως τῶν ρημάτων βιβλίον Αντονίου Αρχουδίου ἀρχυπρεσβητέρου τῆς Σολίτου

msItem.title: Colophon
msItem.colophon: f. i recto Διέγραψεν ὁ Πέτρος ὁ Λησέϋνος Νεοπόλεως

msItem.title: Colophon
msItem.colophon: f. 58v Anno 1610 die 6 Octobris hora 18 hanc Antonii Arcudii arciprespiteri Soleti grammaticam ego Petrus Leseyna discipulus inscribere perfeci

msItem.title: De accentibus
msItem.incipit: f. 59r Accentus est signum quidam scriptum
msItem.explicit: f. 60r aut aspiratur aut levigatur et ἐγὼ ἥρως η et ρ aspiratur
msItem.note: The scribe signed below the end of the text: Petrus Leseynus

support.material:
ff. i-60 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks: ff. 1-60 Quadruped surmounted by letter D
( ca. 30 ca. 30 ) in the gutter, not identifed.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin, right, in ink (ff. i, 1-58) and pencil (ff. 59-60): i + 1-60.

collation.p: The quires are quaternions, the last is a binion. A few stubs are visible, but no leaves have been lost.

supportDesc.condition: The codex is in fair condition. The binding is damaged: the right pastedown has been affected by pest; the spine is split. On the leaves, there are humidity and water stains throughout.

handNote.p: ff. i recto-60r Hand A: the text has been written by Pietro Lasena Lasena, Pietro, 1590-1636 of Naples (Petrus Leseynus, Πέτρος ὁ Λησέϋνος), who signed the manuscript in 1610. The script is an informal minuscule, slanting to the right, with rapid ductus. In the last leaves the script becomes more rapid and inaccurate, and tends to slant more.
The text is written in black ink.

additions.p:
On f. i verso is pasted a slip of paper with four signatures:
Pa. Robertsone wittnes
D. Robertsone wittnes
Duncan Stewart wittnes
Jo. Stewart wittnes.
On the right pastedown is written no 141. It is perhaps an older shelfmark.

binding.p: Early modern limp vellum binding. On the spine there is a paper strip, damaged, with title: [...] Arkudios, Περὶ Συντάξεως τῶν ῥημάτων; under the paper strip are visible traces of ink on the spine. Two paper labels with the present shelfmark are pasted in the upper and lower end of the spine. Red and black points on the edges.
binding.condition: The right joint is nearly completely split. There is extensive pest damage on the right cover: the right pastedown is exposed.

accMat.p: In the manuscript is kept a slip of blue paper with the shelfmark, and a brief description of the contents and binding of the manuscript, probably written by a modern librarian.

origin.p: The manuscript was written in Italy on 6 October 1610 by Pietro Lasena (1590-1636), historian of the Reign of Naples, a pupil of the author of the text, Antonius Arcudius, archpriest of Soleto.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated in 1899 by Reverend Professor John E. B. Mayor (1825-1910) Mayor, John E. B. (John Eyton Bickersteth), 1825-1910 , fellow of St John's College, Cambridge, master at Marlborough College, University Librarian (1864-1866), and Professor of Latin in the University of Cambridge (1872-1910). Stamps of Cambridge University Library on ff. i recto, 1r and 60v.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on P. Easterling, 'Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge', Scriptorium 16 (1962), 302-323 (p. 321).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

analytic.title: Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge
